editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

titleStmt.title: The country captaine and the Varietie, two comedies written by a person of honor ; lately presented by His Majesties servants at the Black-Fryars.
Country captaine
titleStmt.author: Newcastle, William Cavendish, Duke of, 1592-1676.
Newcastle, William Cavendish, 1592-1676.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Hum. Robinson ... and Hum. Hoseley ...,

note.p: Each play has separate paging and special title page: 1) The covntry captaine a comoedye ... Printed by Samuell Broun, 1649; 2) The varietie, a comoedy, ... London: Printed for Humphrey Moseley, 1649.
Pt. 1: Pages 25-51 have print show-through and are tightly bound with loss of text in filmed copy. Pages 22-51 of Pt. 1 Photographed from British Library copy and inserted at end.
Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

sp.p: twelvemonth, thou hast lost thy complexion, by too much study. Why thou shalt be an heir and rule the roost of half a shire, if thy father would but die once, come to the assizes with a band of janissaries to equal the grand signior, all thy tenants shall at their own charge make themselves fine and march, like cavaliers with tilting feathers gaudy as Agamemnon's in the play after whom thou like a saint George on horse back, or the high sheriff, shalt make the country people fall down in adoration of thy crupper and silver stirrup, my right worshipful. A pox on buckram and the luggage in it, papers defiled with court hand and long dashes or secretary lines, that straddle, more than Frenchmen, and less wholesome to the client! Is thy head to be filled with proclamations rejoinder and hard words beyond the alchemist? Be ruled, and live like a fine gentleman, that may have hawks, and hounds, and whores; and horses, and than thou art fit company.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You talk wildly; I would you saw your error; that place all your happiness upon such course delights I should degenerate, and too much forfeit my education.

sp.speaker: Saek.
sp.p:
Education? he has got a tune; I do not think but thou wilt leave thy law, and exercise thy talon in compassing some treatises against long-hair and drinking that most unchristian weed, yclept tobacco: preach to the punies of the inn sobriety and abstinence from shaving of lewd bailiffs
that will come shortly to your chamber doors and there with reverence entreat your worships come forth and be arrested: precious tadpoles: I would not willingly despair of thee; for thy land's sake and cause I am thy countryman: one generous vagary, if thou wert wise, would break some bodies heard, within a seven night, and than thou art lord of all; have but the grace to dine with me at the tavern, and I'll tell thy friends, there is some hope.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: My friends.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Thy father is in Essex, if he live, he will, purchase Rumford if he die sooner, than the town's our own, spend but an acre a day and thou mayest live till all the world be weary of thee; between, us too, what think you of a wench?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: You mean, one wench between us too is nothing; I know a hundred leveretts; things that will bound like a dancer on the rope, and kiss thee in thy natural complexion; a sinner that will climb thee like a squirrel.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: And crack me as a nut; I have no kernel to spare for her sweet tooth.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: That was a metaphor; he is not desperate.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Buy 'My dear captain.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Why farewell countryman. I may live to see thy conversion. Exit.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: How does my uncle.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: He desires presently to speak with you at his lodging.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I'll attend him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: And hast thou been careful of all those things I gave in charge to be provided?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: There is a note of the particulars.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: 'Tis very well done, Thomas, let me see, inprimis.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: The captain will not fail to be with you sir, he was not at his lodging, and enquiring at the horn tavern, I heard he had been there with two or three citizens that owed him money.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: That he owed money too.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: 'Tis all one I think; sir; for when captains have not pay, creditors may pay themselves, here they said, he did mollify the heart of the haberdasher, and drank himself a little mellow ere they parted which gave me some hope I might find him ere night, at the devil, where indeed I fetched him out of the fire, and gave him your letter.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: And the gold too.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
That was the first word he read, if you had written it in text, he could not have found it out so soon, his eye was no sooner on the inside, but his arm flew out with an open month, and his very fingers ends cried give me the gold which presuming to be weight he put into his hocus-pocus a little dormer under his right skirt,
and so taking his word to come down and turning over your horse to him, with some caution, not to be drunk and forget your, worship, I took my leave and went about my inventory.

sp.speaker: Und
sp.p: These things are very right Thomas, let me see now the books of martial discipline.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I bought up all that seem to have relation to war and fighting.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: That was well done; well done; item the sword-salve.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sir if you be hurt you need go no further than the blade for a surgeon.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: The buckler of faith.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: You had the sword before, sir.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: A book of mortification.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I sir, that is a kind of killing, which I thought very necessary for a captain.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Item the book of cannons; Shakespeare's works. Why Shakespeare's works?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I had nothing for the pike men before.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: They are plays.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Are not all your musterings in the country so, sir? pray read on.

sp.speaker: Vad.
sp.p: Bellarmine's controversies, in six tomes.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
That I took upon the stationer's word, who had been a pretty scholar at Paul's; for the word Bellarmine, he said, did comprehend war, weapons and words of defiance ill words provoke men to draw their swords and fighting makes an end of the business
and all this is controversies, pray go on sir.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Two pair of tables; tables? for what?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: O sir for tick-tack; you know it was in my note, which though I doubted at first yet considering you were newly made a captain I conceive it was fit you should learn to set and order your men.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Tactics man; thou didst mistake: they are books of war.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: You cannot know these from books as they are painted I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Why dost thou think these will make a soldier.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Not of themselves, sir, and therefore I provided; please you read on sir.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Parson's resolutions; and Feltham's resolves.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: All is nothing, I know sir without resolution.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Somma totalis 23. 19. and 7. thou hast undone me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: If you do not like the penny worths; 'tis but the charges of myself and a horse again to London: I will lose but the three odd pounds nineteen shillings and sevenpence. It may be you do not understand these authors; when the captain comes, he will expound them to you.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: What a coxcomb have I to my man? but I dare not be angry with him, well, carry them into my study; Thomas. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: My most honoured captain.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: My complete monsieur device: this is a grace to us; you come to visit your mistress my cousin:
And see as if by instinct, she had knowledge of your approach, she is come to meet you: shall I never get opportunity with that she waiter. If I get her with child my man Thomas shall marry her.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sir the captain is newly alighted.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Get a bottle of sack up to my chamber presently.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You are a gentleman of your word.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: And such a gentleman is to be trusted:

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: He is an infidel madam, that will break his word with a lady.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I suspect servant you have many mistresses.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Nor by this white hand, I must acknowledge there are some ladies in the court in whose eyes and opinions I am favoured; I cannot obscure myself from their observations: but my heart with contempt of all other endearments, is only devoted to your service.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Is it not a charge to dress yourself in such varieties of ribbons every day?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Is that your scruple? 'tis the mode to express our fancy upon every occasion; to show the turn, or present state of our hopes or fears in our affections. Your colours, to an understanding lover, carry the interpretation of the heart, as plainly as we express our meaning one to another in characters. Shall I decipher my colours to you now; here is azure and peach. Azure is constant, and peach is love; which signifies my constant affection.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A pretty moral.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: It saves the trouble of writing, where the mistress and servant are learned in this amorous blazon, yesterday I wore fuille-mote; greedeline; and Isabella; fuille-mote is withered, greedeline is absent, and Isabella is beauty: which put together expressed, I did wither or languish for your absent beauty.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: But is there any reason for their distinctions?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Yes lady for example, your fuille-mote is a withered leaf; which does moralize decay; your yellow is joy, because: —

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Why yellow sir is jealous.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p:
No it is your lemon colour, a pale kind of yellow is jealous; your yellow is perfect joy: your white is death, your milk white innocent, your black mourning, your orange spiteful, your flesh colour lascivious, your maid-blush envy, your red is defiance, your gold avaritious, your straw,
plenty, your grass green, hope; your sea green innocent, your violet, religious; your willow, forsaken.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: We may then commit a solecism and be strangely interpreted by some curious expounders in the rash election and wearing of our colours, I perceive.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis pity but there should be some books written for our instructions in this art.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Your hieroglyphic was th' Egyptian wisdom. Hebrews had their cabal; the Romans had their symbol ▪ and impreze, and emblem, but these are absolute. Your modern invention of character, an alphabetical key trite and conspicuous your motto or rebus, too open, and demonstrative but the science and curiosity of your ribbons, is not only instructive but an ornament, and the nearest commentator of love, for as love is entertained first by the eye, or, to speak more plain, as the object affected is taken in first by these optics, which receive the species of things coloured and beautified, so it is answerable to nature that in the progress of our passion we should distinguish by our eye the change or constancy of our affections, in apt, and significant colours.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: You have taken pains, to study this learned blazon.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: It is the only gentile knowledge; or philosophy in the world: I will undertake to open any man or woman's heart: —

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Heaven for bid.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Tell the most secret imaginations and designs, conclude every passion and scruple if they be but careful to observe the artificial method of their colours.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Why this may be a way of fortune telling too.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: You say right lady. Physiognomy and chiromancy are but mere trifles your geomancy mere conjectural, the erection of your scheme circumstantial, and fallible: but your quaint a la mode wear of your fancy, more than astrological.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: 'Tis a kind of divinity.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: You say true madam, and comes near to prophetical, if the minds of ladies and gentlemen were elevated to the sublime consideration.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: What pains he takes to be ridiculous? Aside.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: This gentleman has a notable fancy, and talks poetically.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Yes; yes; he can make verses.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Well I have red authors in my days and knew the length of the poets in my time too which was an hexameter, and which a pentameter, but the wits are not, as they have been, right and straight.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Why Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Why because wind is the cause of many things, now if the wind be not in the right corner, it is, the ill wind, the proverb speaks of, which blows nobody good; for when vapours and wind fly up into the head it
cannot be in two places at one time and that is the reason your men of most wit do seldom love a woman. But here coms my master and sir Francis.

div.stage: Enter sir Richard; sir Francis and master Courtwell.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: This is a double honour to us sir Francis; I shall want language, but not a friendly heart, to entertain you and your noble kinsman. What my exquisite cavalier device? 'tis to no purpose. I see, to remove into the country, to save charges and be quiet, the whole city will come hither, if I stay: I have no stomach to my court knight. Aside.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I hope madam, you will be no enemy to my kinsman.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Sister I present this gentleman; observe and cherish him; he has been in the university.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Any degree sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Only bachelor, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: If he win you to marriage; lady quicksilver.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: He will be master of his art.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: My vote is for him.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I like not the induction of this rival.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: He studies the law: and that is the next high way to preferment, sister.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Indeed it is the high way in which some deliver up their purses: he may climb to scarlett, but that he has too good a face:

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Sir, I hope —

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Troth do not sir; I mean trouble yourself, he is too bashful to prevail upon your spirited mistress. let's leave them.

sp.speaker: Engine.
sp.p: Sir Richard.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: More customers; master engine, welcome. your presence was expected in the country.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: 'Twas my ambition with some intents to serve you, sir, please you vouch safe your privacy, I bring affairs worth your entertainment; I have rid hard.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What cavalier is this uncle?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He is the inventor of new projects cousin, they say, and patents; one that lives like a moth upon the common wealth.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: He looks like one.

sp.speaker: Sir Ric.
sp.p: You will excuse me gentlemen. Make much of sir Francis madam. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We'll leave my nephew and your sister madam: and take a turn in the garden. Exit. with lady.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: You may be confident.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I do not like the fancy in his hat: that gules is war and will be ominous. Exit.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I must seem a modest coxcomb now to preserve my uncle's character.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p:
The gentleman is turned statue, bless me how he stares upon me, and takes root? I think it moves, and now to earth is fixed again; o how it walks and sadly marches
this way? Is't not a ghost? he'll fright me; o; sweet sir, speak if you can and say who murdered you: it points at me: my eyes, ungentle eyes to kill so at first sight, I'll have my looks arraigned for't and small Cupid shall be judge who for your sake will make me blind, as he is.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Lady

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: The man is alive again and has a tongue, discretion guide it; he but sent his soul forth of an errant; 'tis returned; now we shall have some sentences.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Such, are the strange varieties of love, such heats, such desperate colds —

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: No more winter if you love me; unless you can command the coal pits; we have had a hard time of it already, for want of fuel

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: I'm all turned ears, and, lady, long to hear you;
But, pressing to you, doubt I am to near you.
Then I would speak but cannot, naught affords
Expression, the alphabet's too poor in words.
He that knows love knows well that every hour
Love's glad; love's sweet —

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: And some times sour;

These words would go well to a tune, pray let's hear you sing: I do not think but you can make; me a jointure of four nobles a year in ballads, in lamentable ballads, for your wit lies tragical, did not you make the lady's downfall? you express
a passion rarely, but pray leave your couplets, and say something in blank verse before you go.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Before I go; breathe not that killing language;
There is no sun but in your eyes: and when I once take leave of those celestial beams 'tis darkness through the world.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: O; pitiful; if I were a widow then you'd keep me waking for fear I shut my eyes, and your discretion lose the way home.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Where stretched on sable ground, I down shall lay
My mournful body, and with folded arms:
Hear sadder notes upon the Irish harp;
And while my footman plays; sigh out my part,
And drop division with my brinish tears.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: This must be lamentable music sure.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: But I will find an art to cure this wound;
For I with fancies pencil, will so draw
Your picture in the table of my heart
Your absence shall but like dark shadows stand,
To set you of, and see you, lady better
Than love will let me when I look upon you.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: Could this be true and meant, sweet sir, to me;
I should be kinder than the gentlest spring
That warms the world, and makes fierce beasts so tame
and trees to swell themselves to cheerful green
More jocund than the proudest choir of birds,
Whate'er they be, that in the woods so wide
Do sing their merry catches.
Sure he does but counterfeit. Aside.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: O now I see that love
Is sweet; as flowers in their fragrant birth,
Gentle as silk; and kind as clouds to earth.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: One rhythm more and you undo my love for ever, out upon it; peddlers French is a Christian language to this. I had rather you should put me a case out of Littleton: they say you are a pretty lawyer.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Tenant par la courtesy d'angliterre, est son home prent samme selfe en fee simple est fee tail general en self comme heir de la tail especial et ad issu per la mesme feme male ou female apes on nife soit issue apres mort ou en diu de la feme debie la baron tiendra la terra durant sa vie per le ley d'angliterre.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Nay here is enough in conscience: what a noise this confusion of languages makes; this is almost as good as a bear baiting, hark you sir, you are never like to recover me by law.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You are not the first sweet lady; has been overcome in common law.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p:
Not by ten thousand, sir: confessed, but I have no mind to come to issue with a lawyer: when he should consider my case at
home, he'll be at West minster teaching men their statutes! no; no; I will not marry a judge.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Why lady.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: They are casual things and men that hold such strange opinions, they are not safe; no, not in their own lambskins.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Lady you may be misinformed; Astraea hath not quite left the earth and the abuses of some, which shame the calling, are but like patches of beauty on the face of law to set the native whiteness off.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Farewell; sir; you are in love with a bar'd gown, not beauty; if you will follow my learned counsel, leave it. This young thing is a fool or a fine fellow. Exit.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: She kicks and stings out like a colt unweighed. Her wit's a better portion than her money I would not love her, yet, if I could help it. (My uncle and his mistress) I'll not hinder them. Exit.

div.stage: Enter sir Francis and the lady.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: It is no honour, sir, if armed with so much eloquence, you overcome a woman; I blush to say I love you now too much. I wish you would release what your sweet charms won from my tongue: I shall repent my promise.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Make me not miserable after so much blessing. Why, madam, it is upon honourable terms since not upon the first attempt, but, after a tedious siege to your fair love, you give up what shall enrich us both:
it were a sin to fear you can retract what both our lips have sealed, and lose a happiness so near and so secure; your husband holds his pleasure of early hunting constant, and when he pursues his timorous heart tomorrow morning, Cupid will wait, to bring me to Elysium, your bed, where every kiss will new create us.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You must be wise in your excuse to quit his importunity.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Leave that to me. I were not worth the name of him that served you to lose my glorious hope for want of such a thin device; in your thought wish me prosperous and I am fortified against the power of fate to separate us; and when thou art with in the amorous circle of mine arms, we will make laws to love, teach time new actions, or chain him with the cordage of his hair; like a tame thing to wake and watch our pillow; and be our pleasure's sentinel.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I see my husband, 'tis not safe he should observe us. Be wise and constant. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: All that's sweet attend thee. So; I am sailing now to my own Indies: and see the happy coast too; how my wings do spread to catch the wind which coms to cover them. And the green sea enamoured on my bark, doth leap to see how Cupid sits, at the helm and steers my soul to his new world.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: A monopoly, say you, for periwigs?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Been visiting your grounds?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: My hounds rather, sir Francis, and some horses, that takes up my country recreations; 'tis supper time.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Is't not a rare design? and by such art and reasons I can name most beneficial to the common wealth, preventing the diseases which some unwholesome hair breeds in men's heads. It will be worth our agitation sir, and you after the rate of every thousand per annum milked out of the common purse into your own, may easily defalk to me a hundred for my first projection; did I not love you, sir, I could make coin of other able men that would be glad to multiply their money.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Sir I thank you, but have no mind to thrive upon abuse of my prince's favour, nor the people's curse. Here is a gentleman; sir Francis Courtwell, perhaps, will undertake it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What; sir Richard?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: A monopoly for composing and selling of periwigs.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Excuse me sir, I dare not deal in them; do not you hear things of this nature questioned?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: How sir questioned?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: There's one among the rest, I cannot hit upon his name in fair election to be hanged, one engine.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: O sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What ail you sir?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: A megrim in my head.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Who's there? look to master engine here, he faints, and send to your lady for some cordial waters presently.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: There is a sovereign well hard by, has done strange cures, please you; I'll throw him into that. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Though I distaste his business, I would not he should miscarry here, you frighted him. 'tis supper time, I shall expect your company in the morning, sir Francis: I have a pack of dogs will make the forest ring.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I'll carefully attend sir: as early as you please I love the sport too.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I wish we had all pleasures to delight you; but nothing wants in my true love to serve you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yet I must cuckold him, I cannot help it.

div.head: Actus tertius. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Sir Richard and his lady in bed enter Thomas (With sir Richard's boots.)

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Who is that? Thomas?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
The sun is up before you sir, here
be your boots.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: That's well.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Prithee do not rise, it is hardly day, sirrah, who bid you call him so early? Sir Richard will not rise yet.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I cannot help it, 'tis none of my fault.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Where is Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Here, madam; what make you up so soon, Thomas.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: O mistress Dorothy 'tis even long of you for between sleep and wake your remembrance came to me this morning, and Thomas was up presently.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: You must excuse me; I mean to kill a brace of hares before you think 'tis day. Come, on with my boots. Thomas; and Dorothy go you to sir Francis chamber tell him the day grows old and I am ready: our horses and our merry hounds expect us. Exit Dorth.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Any excuse to leave me.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: You may take your ease in bed still madam, I'll not lose one morning, that invites so pleasantly, to hear my dogs, for a new maidenhead. 'twas for these sports and my excess of charge I left the town; besides the city fogs and steam of brickhills almost stifled me. This air is pure, and all mine own.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: My lady means she would have you get another heir sir for your land, though, it be against my master the young captain yet she speaks but reason and now, I talk of the captain, sir. would you had given him council.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: To what.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Before he took this huffing trade upon him to have been a man of peace, I mean, a justice, nature has made him fits for both a like; he is now at charge to keep a captain schoolmaster: he might have saved the quarterage of his tutor if I had been his clerk, and then the in come that broken heads bring in; and new years gifts from soadred virgins and their she provincials whose warren must be licenced from our office. —

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Away you prating knave; what is he ready?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alas he's almost dead.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: How dead?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: He has been troubled with a fit of the stone sir, all this night poor gentleman, he groans and sweats and cannot: —

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Make urine sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I heard my lady has an excellent receipt to cure the stone. She is a piece of a rare surgeon.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Wellaway and get the horses ready; sirrah; or I shall ride you and your wit together.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Alas any fool may ride me, but I would fain see any man ride mistress Dorothy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How sirrah.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p:
I am sorry I must leave such a companion but more lament the cause, I wish
him health: my presence cannot serve him, morrow wife, I will not lose my sport. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.p: Nor she; when you are gone; my lady does expect another bunts up

sp.speaker: Dad
sp.p: Now I must trust thy service.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You shall not doubt me; madam; and to assure you my faith, I have a suit to your ladyship, whose grant, were there no other bonds upon me, would tie me to everlasting silence.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What is't; but name it and I shall soon confirm thee

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Our captain of the train band has been offering to chaffer maidenheads with me; I must confess I can affect the fool. upon good terms, and could devise to noose my amorous woodcock if you assist me privately, and dare trust me with some jewel of price, that is not known, which shall be faithfully restored, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I that dare trust my honour with thee, shall not suspect thy faith in any treasure else, choose from my cabinets, but, prithee, draw the curtains while I expect this friend, I needs must hide my blushes thou mayst discover from my gallery window when they are horsed, I tremble, to consider what I have promised.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Tremble to meet a ghost; you are more fearful than a virgin; madam; why this sets me a longing, but I'll watch: this is the timorous world of flesh and blood. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Alas what do you mean? retire for heaven's sake: my husband is not gone, I heard his voice yet, this rashness will undo my fame for ever, should he return.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: How's this? retire for heaven's sake, my husband is not gone, I heard his voice this will undo my same. It was my wife and this is sure my bed chamber. She looks out.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I have undone myself, it is my husband.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: My forehead sweats; where are you; madam; whom did you talk too; or take me for? Ha; asleep already; or do I dream; I am all wonder; madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Nay; nay kill him; if it please you; sweet heart, I cannot abide a blackamoorFeigns sleeping.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: How's, this? wife.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Help, help, dear husband strangle him with one of my lute strings; do, do, do.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: If she be asleep : she was nor wont to talk thus, she has had some hideous dream, she spoke to me, too. Who should I strangle sweet heart, with a lute string?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: The King of Morocco I think.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: It is so, she dreams, what strange chimaeras we fancy in our sleep: I were best wake her, madam, madame.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Sweet heart, madam, wake.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Sir Richard? ôh, you have delivered me from such a dream I quake to think upon it.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I must confess you frighted me at first.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My master come back? if he had found the sick sir Francis here.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: How, now, art thou frighted, too.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Frighted quoth 'a; o madam; the key of the closet, quickly, I must have some cordial water for sir Francis I fear this fit will kill him.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Alas good gentleman make haste.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: His appearance would betray all thus prevented. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p:
Nay sweet heart, you shall not leave me till I told what a cruel dream I had, methought a King of blackamoors was in love with me, and having, by flattering courtship drawn me to his bed chamber, by my consent, or force, swore to enjoy me. I knew not by what reasons to divert the ravisher; but told him that I heard thy voice, I bid him if he loved his life retire, for thou wouldst, (Dear,) revenge my honour, but he pursuing me, I cried out murder and having never a sword, I counseled thee to strangle him with a lute string; for which cruelty of mine methought he threw an arrow at me, which
if thou hadst not waked me as thou didst would, as I slept; with my strong fears have killed me.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: This was the King of Morocco; well, I am glad I came to take away thy fright.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: But, sweet, you left me, with a resolution to hunt this morning, have you done already?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: The thieves prevented me, my stable has been robbed tonight , two geldings and my Roan nag are vanished.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Nay do not thou vex, I have sent hue and cry that may overtake them; but come I'll leave thee to thy glass, and visit sir Francis, now she is returned. How does your noble guest? Enter Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: He is pretty well, sir he has voided one stone since and now finds ease.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis well, attend your mistress. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O wench, I had almost undone myself, come on the other side, reach me that petticoat. I le tell thee the story as I make me ready. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Is it possible you can talk thus, and be no scholar?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I have travelled in my fancy: took the air about the world with the muses, and do for my recreation of wit, compose some wonders in verse, poetical essays: as one upon report of a heat that was in Egypt.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Let's hear them.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.l: In countries I have been;
Under the equinoctial, where I have seen
The sun disperse such a prodigious heat
That made our sieve-like skins to rain with sweat:
Men would have given, for an eclipse, their lives
Or one whisper of air, yet each man strives
To throw up grass, feathers; nay women too
To find the wind, all falls like lead, none blue,
The dog star spits new fire, till't came to pass
Each eye became his neighbours' burning glass.
Lean men did turn to ashes presently
Fat men did roast to lean anatomy.
Young women's heat did get themselves with child
For none but they themselves, themselves defiled.
Old women naturally to witches turned
And only rubbing one another, burned.
The beasts were baked, skin turned to crust they say
And fishes in the river boiled away
Birds in the air were roasted, and not burned
For, as they fell down, all the way, they turned.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Most excellent.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I have seen larks in that motion at fire with an engine of packthread perpendicular.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: What would they have given for a shower in those countries'.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Now you talk of a shower, you shall hear another copy of verses that I made of a mighty rain which fell once in the Indies.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: That you made? if you will venture your lungs let me hear some more impossible storeys to pass away the time.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.l: Heaven did not weep, but in its swelling eye
Whole seas of rheum and moist catarrhs did lie
Which so bespauld the lower world men see
Corn blasted, and the fruit of every tree,
Air was condensed to water 'gainst their wish
And all their fowl was turned to flying fish,
Like watermen they thronged to ply a fair
And thought it had been navigable air.
Beasts lost the natural motion of each limb.
Forgotten to go with practicing to swim.
A trout now here, you would not think how soon
Ta'en ready, dressed for the empress of the moon.
The fixed stars, though to our eyes were missing
We knew yet were by their continual hissing
Women were mermaids sailing with the wind,
The greatest miracle was fish behind.
But men were all kept chaste against their wish
And could commit but the cold sin of fish.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: And that sin would puzzle all the civil lawyers in the kingdom. Sins of the flesh they are perfect in, they know well enough what belongs to adultery and simple fornication: but you would much improve and oblige the practice of the court if you could bring this sin of fish under their commission. But now I hope the rain is over; and we shall have fair weather.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Now can I tell you lady, what a. strange frost was in one part of the world

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I shall cry out fire if you do: I'd rather have some discourse to keep me warm.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Or how the whole world was troubled with the wind colic.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: No more earth quakes I beseech you: some friends of mine lost a great deal of land the last term and for ought I know, 'tis never to be recovered. Why all these verses you have honoured me to hear, were translated out of French.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: You say very true lady.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: No, no; they are out of Spanish as I remember.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I think it be out of Spanish indeed.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Or else out of the Italian.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Troth madam; I know not which very well.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p:
And yet you made them: some gentlemen have the faculty to make verses, and
forget what language, was the original. 'tis a la mode, I confess, sir.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: There is the mischief in poetry; a man might have told a hundred lies in prose upon his own name and never miscarry, but leaving these lewd rhymes, lady, how do you like the novice that sir Richard commended.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Master Courtwell?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Is he not a pretty chrisom; I could not choose but laugh to observe in what rural deportment he came to salute you that should have made his address in these postures: —

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: It is enough, sir, I apprehend what you would do: the truth is, touching that thing in black; I do not love him.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I know 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Why is it impossible? The man is a pretty indifferent meaning man but I must have one of a more active spirit: no, no; the man is a coward.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: He looks like one.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p:
I put him to it, he dares not fight, and he that expects my favour to so high a degree as marriage, must be none of my lord mayor's whifflers; he must be valiant in arms; I am not taken with a ring or a carcanet as some avaricious ladies: he that presents me with the sword of his rival, is more welcome than all the silken soft natured 600. a year widgeons that will be baffled in their best clothes; and go down into the country every vacation, like attorneys
to be beaten against the next tear me, and get damages by it. But I forget some affairs that concerns me, and take my leave: your deserts upon me are eminent and many; and for all your noble services, I will promise you nothing, you apprehend me. —

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: 'Tis too much, sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I am so weary I can stay no longer with you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: You make me over happy, so; so; the matters done. I may visit my friends; hum! well thought upon, I shall leave her joys without any bound to entertain me, if I first beat this foolish rival of mine, and present her with his sword; she assures me he dares not fight: it shall be so, thus with one baffeling and disarming him I shall secure my mistress; and get the reputation of a fighting cavalier, which may save me many knocks here after, among men of strong faith, that shall hear how much honour I have else where taken up upon the ticket. Exit.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p:
Stand right to your files, — make even your ranks, — silence — front to the right hand, — as you were, — to the right hand about, — by the left hand, as you were, — ranks — to the right, double — ranks as you were, — ranks to the left double, — middle men to the right hand double the front, — middle men to the
right entire, double the front — files to the right, — to the left, — to the right hand — counter march to the right — to the left — wheel about. —

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Rantan! enough, you must not, waste your lungs at once; march fair and make a captain. When these words of command are rotten, we will sow some other military seeds; you bear a brain and memory.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Sact.
sp.p: And now you are chosen a captain for the country, you must give good example to your soldiers, and cherish nature: after excercise you must drink sack; sack is a fortifier. Come we'll to the town.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: With all my heart;Enter master court.
Here is one master Courtwell let us take him with us.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: My costive countryman; he's an Anabaptist, he will not drink, and yet he kissed the cup oft; last night, methought , when his mistress drank to him. We'll try; how is't, my man of moral breeding?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: My man of war, Tresbone; your servant, captain.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p:
Why this was spoke like one of us, canst do't again? thy voice is more authentic, sounds as I have heard a cavalier in a tavern; or like the merry master of the dragon. Small Neptune, that controls the rich canaries when he commands the Tritons of his cellar; scud and bring wine you varlets, with a flavour for my nobility;
we were conspiring to go to the tavern.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I'll make one gentlemen; to waste away some melancholy.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Spoke boldly like an Argonaut.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I am not now in London; upon a hall day marching with the puinees twenty of us in a teem, to Westminster in our torne gowns embroidered with strand dirt, to hear the law.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Is not thy father dead? thou talkest so well? how I was cozened 'In thee; come a way.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Here's my man Thomas.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Now the news, sir Tristram?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: O; the gentleman is mad.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: What gentleman?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Why master engine, that did faint last night.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: With fear of being hanged for his projections.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: My uncle told me of him.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Send him to bedlam then; what makes he here? clean straw and a good whip are held restoratives.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: He walks and talks the madliest, twenty midwives are nothing to him, he drowns all their noise his tongue is twenty rings of bells; and yet he seems so merry.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p:
Save you gentlemen; gallants; cavaliers; how far travel you? methinks
you are finely accommodated: are you a doctor sir?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: No; but I can tell you; how to purge if it please you.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: You say very well; troth gentlemen you must pardon me; cry you mercy: your name is captain Underwit.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Yes, sir: but my mother came of the Overmuches by the Peake: she broke my father's heart, and sir Richard buried her. Things must be as please the stars.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: What think you; of the blazing start in Germany according to Ptolemy? 'tis very strange; does the race hold at Newmarket for the cup? when is the cooking, gentleman there are a parcel of rich jewels to be sold now if a man had money: I do mean to build a very fine house next summer, and fish ponds. What did you hear of the new play? I am afraid the wits are broken, there be men will make affidavit, they have not heard a good jest since Tarleton died: pray may I crave your name sir?

sp.speaker: C●urt..
sp.p: My name is Courtwell sir.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: In your ear, I have a cast of the best marlens in England: but I am resolved to go no more by water, but in my coach: did you ever see the great Shipp?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: I have been one of the twenty that have dined in her lantern.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p:
It may be so, she is a good sailer; but, I'll tell you one thing, I mean to have the best pack of hounds in Europe, sir Richard
loves the sport well, and then if I can but find out the reason of the load stone, I were happy and would write non ultra.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: The philosopher's stone were better in my opinion: have you no project to get that?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: That has startled him; I doubt this fellow does but counterfeit. Aside.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: What think you of the dromedary, that was to be seen on the back side of the bell?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: I have seen a stranger beast.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: So have I; I have seen you before now, sir.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Why then I'll tell you; the strangest beast that ever I saw was an ostrich that eat up the iron-mines: but, now you talk of birds, I saw an elephant beat a tailor in the fencing school, at his own weapon.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: The Spanish needle?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: He did out eat him in bread, and that was miraculous, I have seen a catamountain once, but all was nothing, to the lady, that turned round and threaded needles.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Troth sir I think you have turned round too, and are not settled yet.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p:
Now you talk of settling I knew a gentleman, that was born to a great fortune, should all his land, went to sea in a Hollander, was taken by a dunkirk, at 7. years and stole away in a English bottom after that, saw both the Indies, for all this, was taken by a Turkish man of war put into the galleys, and, for ought I hear by credible
report, is not settled yet.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sure he is a great scholar; a man cannot understand him.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: His brains are out of tune.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Now you talk of music; there is no man in the world loves music better than I: I'll give you the reason: I have been deaf almost this half year; it came with a cold sitting up at primero.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Now you talk of a cold, it puts me in mind of the new device of fire, for brewing and baking: had you no hand in that project?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Again he is startled: come he shall to the tavern with us and confess all; if he does not strip his soul stark naked to us; say I am no fortune teller.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: What think you of a cup of medium wine?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: That will spoil all: please you to honour our society? we are going to indulge at the tavern.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: O the neat's tongues and asparagus that I have eaten at the stillyard! But of all things in the world I do not love a black cat, next a brewer's cart, there is nothing will stay a man so much in the night as a constable; one word before you go and I beseech you give me your opinion clearly; was not the Morocco ambassador, a very fine gentleman for a pagan?

sp.speaker: Sac.
sp.p: Yes sure; and the lead mines in Derbyshire hold still. Marry for the allome businesses — but come, will you walk?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p:
I do use to go a foot some times, but
when I ride; and than I must confess there's no striving with the stream: you were in London lately they say the people are more affected to bear-baiting then in former time.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: There are some of late are drawn like bears to a stake but for your own part the gout and the grand pox are all one to you: what price bears meat in the shambles?

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: Flesh rises and falls; as it uses to do; sir: but a country life is the best when all is done: are we all of one religion? what think you of a bridge from lion key to Flandres, you may guess I talk at random, gentlemen, but you must not interpret all foolish discourse a distemper of the brain; lords would take it for a scandalum magnatum, and your ladies would be angry too; now you talk of ladies.

div.stage: Enter sir Francis and the lady.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: By no means master engine: that gentleman loves you not. Come, I le bring up the rear, where is Thomas?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I'll follow sir; I would give my 4. marks a year that I could talk like that mad gentleman; he's here, and there, and everywhere : how will his tongue run when his cogs are oiled? they'll drench him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Although I missed a happiness, I your nimble wit that secured both our honours: you have an excellent instrument to your gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O she delivered so toth' life, how you were troubled with the stone, at first I did believe't myself, and think of the sad consequence: but time is precious now; although our stars have not been yet propitious to our meeting, I'll try my art tonight to make them shine with happy influence on our loves.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: Most excellent, madam; how?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I'll not engage your visit to my chamber, since the first proved so unfortunate, but come to yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: This night? won't your husband be at home?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: You enjoy but one bed?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Without witchcraft sir. I have a stratagem to delude my husband and all his jealous waking eyes: a plot that cannot fail, if you dare but expect me.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.p: I grow immortal with my hopes, and fancy more than the world's most glorious empire, in my first embrace, I should run back into an infant once again, and by degrees and time, grow up to meet so vast a happiness: ages in expectation spent were poor and easy sufferings weighed against this triumph. Methinks I am not man, but something of a more exalted essence, humane nature hath not capacity to understand and own these precious blessings.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p:
No more rapture, but with the confidence of a lover, spread your equal thoughts, and in your heart and arms prepare an entertainment for that guest that hath no life nor name but what you give. A kiss, and leave our souls to think
upon the joys this night attends us.

sp.speaker: Sir Fran.
sp.l: Sullen day
Do not tire now 'tis down hill all the way.

div.head: Actus quartus scaena prima.
div.stage: A catch sung, after which enter Thomas with a cloak and a sword.

lg.l: Come let us throw the dice who shall drink,
Thine is twelve and his since sink.
Six and four is a cast,
Six and three not too fast.
Come aloft sink trey,
Since ace fair play,
Cator duce is your throw sir,
Cator ace they run low sir.
Two deuces we see,
Deuce ace is but three.
O where is the wine, come fill up his glass,
For here is the man that has thrown Amsace.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
They are all drunk already, and such a confusion in their heads and tongues: my master kisses the next man and calls him mistress Dorothy, master Courtwell possessed with the spirit of defiance to Cupid is ready to beat him for being in
love. My projector's dead drunk in a chair, and the captain peeping into his mouth like a tooth-drawer and pouring down sack, which he feels not, but his chaps shut again like a spring-lock, till he return with a key to open his teeth to pour in the next health.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: My cloak and sword drawer.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: 'Tis here sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Thou art a pretty fellow; there's half a crown, say I am gone Thomas.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: You are a petty well.

sp.speaker: Under.
sp.p: What shall's do with him? this engine burns like Aetna.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Throw him into the river.

sp.speaker: Under.
sp.p: He's able to mull the Thames. Well for mine own part, would mistress Dorothy were here to open her files.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Did not you name a woman?
I will have no mention of any thing that's female.

sp.speaker: Under.
sp.p: May not a man talk of sack?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Sack is a sovereign medicine.

sp.speaker: Under.
sp.p: O very sovereign.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: It is hic et hac sack, both for he and she. Stay, is my countryman gone? come my Apollo's, my Orpheus', or my Bacchus his minstrels; which to leave poetical expressions, in broader phrase, is tavern fiddlers, some of your tunes my masters, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Musi.
sp.p: Do you mean master Adson's new airs sir?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Ay sir. But they are such fantastical airs as it puts a poet out of his wits to rhyme to them but let me hear —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No I do not like that? —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Nor that: no, no, no, neither:

sp.speaker: Musi.
sp.p: An't please your worship master captain our boys can sing songs to these.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No, no, saving your presence, your boys have nothing surreverence but love songs, and I hate those things monstrously to make things appear better than they are, and that is but deceptio visus, which after some embracing, the parties see presently what it is.

div.stage: The captain sings and reels, then Phillips all the while with his fingers. (After speaks.)

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Ay, ay, this thumping tune I like a life; a song, a song to it.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: The juice of Spanish squeezed grapes is it
That makes a dull brain so full of wit,
So Lemonado's clear sparkling wine
The grosser wits too doth much refine,
Than to be foxed it is no crime,
Since thickest and dull brains it makes sublime.
The Stilyard's Rhenish wine, and devils white,
Who doth not in them sometimes take delight?
If with mimic gestures you'll keep you from sadness
Then drink lusty claret, 'twill make you in madness.
And then to settle you no hopes in beer,
But wholesome pots of Scotch ale though 'tis dear.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: But hark you child, you say in your song the devil's white, you have been ill catechised boy, for a white devil is but a poetical fiction, for the devil bless us child is black.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No captain, I say white wine at the devil.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: That's true, that's a good boy indeed — Underwit, lend me a piece, lend me a piece to give these harmonious men — there, — and now be gone my masters; without noise, for I will have no more fiddle-faddles for my money; no tunes of supererogation after the musical bill is paid, —Exit music.
Come hither Thomas, do you think I am drunk?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Truly captain, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You cannot tell, there's your ignorance, drink is a vice I am as little given to as another, for I do abhor it in myself, I do wonder how any reasonable man can be drunk, etc. — man can be drunk, therefore every wise man take counsel and example by me, and he may see very plainly what an odious thing it is, for you must follow your leader, and virtue which is an ancient —

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Virtue an ancient?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Ay, an ancient old gentlewoman, that is grown very poor, and nobody knows where she dwells, very hard to find her out, especially for a captain, you will find it very difficult for a lieutenant, but we will endeavour the best we can. You see my courses, I have travelled to find her out, and I could never yet see her at a bawdy-house?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.l: Who is this to be seen at a bawdy-house?
To the right-hand — countermarch.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: He talks of virtue sir.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Virtue? she never comes there, why do you think she should be there captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why? because she is an old gentlewoman, and might keep the house.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Alas captain mistress virtue is poor and lean.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Nay then she is not fit to be a bawd; but tell me, did you ever see her, or if so, did you ever —

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: No, but 'twas none of my fault. I know not what I may do in time, when she understands the words of command.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: He does not mean mistress Dorothy; but captain, I would fain know the reason why your bawds are so fat still?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A plain case, they lie fallow and get heart, than they keep themselves so in health, and so soluble with stewed prunes, and then sipping of sack is a great matter to fatten them. But they are as good people as a man can keep company withal, and bring up the young gentlewomen so virtuously; I came into one of their houses tother day for a career, and I found the bawd very sick upon her deathbed, very religious, and much given to repentance, for those poor sins she had committed; when she had taken order for her soul, she told me the young gentlewoman I looked for was in the next room, and desiring her upon her blessing to give me content, she turns her to the wall, and gives up the ghost very privately, because she was loath to trouble us.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p:
By your relation captain, these appear
to be very good people what if we went to visit one of these matrons? I have a great mind to exercise

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Why you speak like an understanding soldier and one that may come to something in the end, therefore let us march on.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: March on to Venus' wars.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: For you know, Thomas that the spider and the bee do something, but I have forget what it is.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, come let us go.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Go? no more but go, though I be a captain if I have not commission in this employment, —

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: What then captain?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Why then I cannot go.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Very right. Exit.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Do you hear captain? for all this; I have a great mind to a wench, and a wench I must have, if there be one above ground; ôh, ôh; London; London. Thou art full of frank tenants, give me London shall we wheel about thither, yet?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Give you London? will not Cheapside serve your turn or the exchange?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: O gentlemen, master engine is truly bewitched.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Bring the witch and master engine before us.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: He does vomit the strangest things yonder. —

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Did not I say, murder will out?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I think he has eaten and drunken nothing but monopolies: and, being too hard to be digested they all come up again, I must hold his head. Within:o

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Did not I tell you something would come out?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Pins; pins; they lay cross his throat, I told you he was bewitched? Hey day cards and dice, and with them the devil is a gamester. And pays the box soundly, now; now; now:Within:oh.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: What's that.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: 'Tis something clammy; ôh 'tis soap.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Soap? give a man leave to wash his mouth.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Does not the lime burn his throat Thomas?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Alas poor gentleman, something now again is ready to strangle him, I think they are hides, and the horns stuck in his gullet, well strained! what a foul stomach he has:Within:oh.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Open his mouth, thrust down a pottle pot.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I have sir; and it is come up full of medium wine. If you have any charity come and help to hold his head: now again.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: O; o; o:

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: 'Tis very straying captain; the man is certainly enchanted.

sp.speaker: Eng.
sp.p: O; oh.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
Master master; heigh! will you take tobacco in the roll? here is a whole shiplading, variety of Bermoda's and one
little two penny paper of Verina's, with a super subscription, to my very friends of the custom house.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Put up that for a relic, Thomas: and open it upon high days to clear the fore eyes of your Spanish merchants, Thomas; no more, but call the drawer, an understanding drawer and one writes orthography and do you pay the reckoning.

Sirrah I charge you set a padlock on the chamber door: there is a dangerous fellow must be brought to his purgation and look all the goods that he hath vomited be forth coming. While we discreetly go and inform the magistrates: at your peril sirrah, at your peril: seal up the door and do you pay the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Sir Richard is a justice; there's your money, and yet we need not pay; the gentleman hath left enough for the reckoning in the next room.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: I have made him fast; you're very welcome gentlemen: all is paid in the portcullis . Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I'll walk no further; if you have a secret to impart, you need not fear this place. The trees, and hedges will not listen, what is the business? I hope your phlegmatical stock of verse is spent.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Why then in prose the worst that I can speak; I do not love you lady.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: How? you have not trained me thus far to tell me that?

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: You are. —

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: You do not mean to quarrel, now you have betrayed me to the field, and beat me, sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What is there in your face more, to attract me, than that red cow's complexion? why the devil do you think, I should dote upon your person? that thing when she is stroked gives milk.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: By that I understand, all this is in revenge, because you think I did neglect you: pray, sir, tell me, and tell me seriously; put the case that I should love you: could you love again?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: In troth, I think I could not.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Do you but think:

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I will bind it with an oath before the parish.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: What reasons?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I shall be loath to say your eyes are twinkling stars again your lips twin cherries, and out blush the rubies; your azure veins vie beauty with the saphire: or that your swelling breast are hills of ivory pillows for Jove to rest his amorous head. When my own conscience tell me that Bunn-hill is worth a hundred of them, and but high gate compared with them is a paradise, no I thank you.

sp.speaker: S●st..
sp.p: But how come you so cured? you were a passionate, I may say, fool, in hope you will deserve it: what physic took you, that hath thus restored you?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: A little sack had power to cure this madness.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I hope you are not sober yet; the humour may change when you have slept.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I'll rather stitch my eye lids up with sisters-thread, and stare perpetually.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: When you may see me again.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I think I shall not, unless it be to wonder when you are in that ivy bush; that face cut upon taffeta, that cream and prunes so many plumbs in white broth, that scutcheon of pretence. powdered with ermines. How sell you grapes? your hair does curl in bunches: your lips look like the parson's glebe; full of red, blue, and yellow flowers; how they are chapped and look like trenches made to drain the meadows?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: This rudeness is beyond the manner of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I cannot help it and I hope you think so.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: But if your passion have not drowned all reason; I pray let us part civilly.

sp.speaker: Court
sp.p: With all my heart, I dare then take my leave too.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Who is that.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Where.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Behind that tree.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You have no plot t'accuse me for a rape? was at the worst, but felony with cherries, that look as if they had been a fort night gathered:

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I know you'll bring me home in courtesy.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Not I; I will not trust myself and you: fare well lady: do you see that bull?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: That is a happy beast.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Why happy sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: He writes no verses to his mistress, is not cozened nor forsworn: to get her favour, bestows no rings, nor empties his exchequer to appear still in new rich suits but lives free upon the stock of nature, yet loves none. Like the great Turk, he walks in his seraglio and doth command which concubine best pleases, when he has done, he falls to graze or sleep, and wakes, as he had never known the dun, white, red, or brinded cow.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: You are unmanly.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Nay, I know you will rail now: I shall like it: call me a scurvy fellow, proud, and saucy, and ill bred crooked clown, I'll hear. This, rather than live upon your pity, and yet do not: for if you rail too men that know you can dissemble, may believe you love me, and 'tis not my aim.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: You are a fine man

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I am in my best clothes.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I perceive 'tis true now, what the world says of you, and yet 'tis strange.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: 'Tis strange it should be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p:
You give your tongue a licence, nor will I hope your malice should spare me a broad, that have so prodigally abused a lady's fame that deserves nobly from you; but you men care not whose name you blast
with a loose character, so you maintain your pride of talk.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: How is this? it is confessed I have talked in my time and talked too much, but not too much of you; for I but seldom thought of such a woman, or any other.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Nay sir I am satisfied, you can talk your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Have I not done it, too?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Yes by your own report, and with a lady so much in virtue and in birth above you? And therefore I expect not your modest language of me.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Stay. This moves me; I never took a pleasure yet to lie with lady's fames: or ever thought that sport lie in the tongue; such humours are for men: that live by brothel offices, let me but know who hath traduced me to you thus, he shall be known no more.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I'll not be guilty sir: of any murder; when we meet again and you in better humour I may tell you: so farewell Gondarino, nothing's lost when you turn woman hater. Exit.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: She has vexed me, if we two make a matrimony after this rate, the devil is like to dance at our wedding. Enter device.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: He's here, a lone too, and the place most opportune! how shall I begin. Master Courtwell, do you love any friend of mine?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Not to my knowledge, sir, I should be sorry.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Do you not love a gentlewoman, sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: If she be a friend of yours, I'll take the first occasion to neglect her, for your sake.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: It will become your wisdom, and your safety.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What mischief have you done to your face?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: My face?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You look so scurvily, come hither thou new monster, with more feet than a caterpillar what time of the day is it? you that move upon so many wheels, say monsieur, are you not a walking clock; I have a mighty mind to see you took in pieces.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I do not like this: you cannot put me, sir, together again.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I will not take the pains, why do you smile now?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: At your conceit, to think I was o'clock I am a watch; I never strike, he's valiant. Aside.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You have pretty colours their are these your mistresses.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: If you did know the mystery you would applaud them: you have read lieure de B'azone, what mean you?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I will bestow them upon some fore-horse; they will become a country team rarely.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Morr ▪ dieu! why you dare fight it seems, and I was told, you were no cavalier: a very dream, a wedge for men to break their swords upon, I shall never trust fame again for your sake.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Thou never did'st cozen me. —

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I was never so illiterate in a man.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: For I did ever think thou durst not fence but at a complexion, a glistering vapour: a thing of clothes, and fit for chambermaids to whet their wits upon: but now resolve either to have your skin flayed off; or fight with me for troubling my present meditations.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Why sir if you be serious I shall quit that prejudice you have upon my valour look you sir I can draw, and thus provoke I dare chastise you, too cause I was merry I am not bound to feed your spleen eternally with laughter, yet I am not ignorant what an advantage, sir, your weapon gives you in length.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: We'll change why this is honour in thee. They measure and device gets both weapons.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Now, sir, keep of.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Sure thou art not so base.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I never cozened you, do you remember? these two will guide me on the rope.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You mean to dance then.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Yes but with quicker time than you I hope can follow. Thus I begin; fa la, la. Exit.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What a heathen coward is this? how the rogue trips like a fairy: to the town with them, he has been a footman sure I have not breath enough to overtake him, and 'twill be dark presently if I lose the sight of him; I'll search the town and if I find him not there, pursue him with hue and cry, and after hang him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: The sun, whose busy eye is still employed a spy upon our actions, tired with waiting is drowsy gone to bed, about whose pillow night hath hung all her wings, and set up tapers as if the day were timorous like a child and must have light to sleep by, welcome all the hours that govern pleasure, but be slow when you have blessed me with my wishes, time and love shall dwell like twins, make this your bower and charm the air to sweetness, and to silence: favour me now, and you shall change your states: time shall be old no more, I will contract with destiny, if he will spare his wings, to give him youth and beauty, that we may find every minute a fresh child of pleasure: love shall be proud to be no more a boy but grow to perfect strength and hold consistence: for when two active lovers meet so happy as we whose equal flames do light embraces 'twill be no weight to number many years in our delights and think all age a blessing: but language is too narrow to express what I expect, 'tis fit my soul retire till she present herself, and if it can measure my hoped-for joys with thoughts prepare to entertain the happiness. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Dorothy (With a light) to sir Richard and his lady, (In bed)

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
I have set already my design a
moving to take my captain, Underwit, who in wine was late more fierce upon me; in the mean time I cannot choose but laugh at the device we hope to cheat my master with sure the devil is a great friend to women that love men! He doth so furnish us with quaint inventions: presently after supper, she began her sit of tooth ache, and did counterfeit so naturally; but since she went to bed she almost raved by turns; I heard her at it.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O o; who's there.

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.p: 'Tis I for sooth, I heard you groan and I have not the heart to sleep, shall I watch by you?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O no! get you to bed, make fast the chamber: I cannot endure. —

div.stage: Dorothy puts out the candle at the door and returns.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Dear heart, be patient.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Ay, you have your homilies of patience, but if you had my pain, it would make you mad, o; o.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I'll send for the French tooth drawer in the morning.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: There is no rack nor torture like it, o; what shall I do; I shall never sleep again.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Which tooth is it.

sp.speaker: Do●.
sp.p: The sweet one you may be sure troubles her

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: This, this; o that there. —

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: They are happy that are old and have no teeth.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O take heed; now it shoots up to my head.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Thou makest my headache with thy noise.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: If you knew what I suffer, your head would ache, in deed, I must rise and walk in the chamber, there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: Ser Rich.
sp.p: You'll catch more cold.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: O no; dear life do not cross me; if you were in my torment, you would rise; and try any thing, for a little ease it cannot be worse the pain sure came with a cold and who knows but another cold may cure me.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I prithee come to bed again.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: So, so do not trouble me. I am now in some little ease it is a heavenly thing to be going.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Dost thou hear?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Your noise will bring my pain back again, if you knew what a vexation it is for me to speak you would not put me to it so, if you do talk I will not answer a word more. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Well! by this no light I'll to London tomorrow. I see 'tis possible a woman's tooth may be as trouble so me, as her tongue

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O; o.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I cannot choose but pity her: that any woman should hold so much pain in a hollow tooth!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
If my master touched with so much compassion should rise and force me to bed
to him, I must not cry out a rape. 'tis at the worst on my side, but fornication in my own defence.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Prithee come to bed.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O; o; o:

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: The music at a convocation of cats, at a witch's upsitting is the spheres to this caterwauling. I will thrust my head into the pillow, as Diana did, in the bush when the bear was coming, and then I shall not hear her.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh! this is a kind of purgatory for the sins of the flesh: if she should fall asleep with the other knight; it is not possible I should hold out till morning that which would fright away an ague hath put me into a fever: I shall have the tooth ache in deed with counterfeiting. I have known some men taught the stammers so, my gums do murmur, there is fear all over my flesh she will stay too long, and then, —

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Uh; uh:

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O; o; I'll shift places to show more distraction at the worst my noise shall be within his reach it may give her warning to return too. Exit.

div.stage: Enter lady to sir Francis ( asleep ) a table ink and paper set out.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p:
I am full of fears and my own motion frights: me this furious love is a strange pilot: sir where are you, ha; asleep ? can any dulness that is not death possess a gentleman so valiant in desires, when he
expects to meet his mistress? how I blush to raise him? was I not worth thy waking expectation, farewell: yet something like a chain that's fastened to my poor heart restrains me, ink and paper:Writes.
I'll leave him a short monument of his shame and my neglected love. He knows my hand, farewell forgetful lover. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.

div.head: Actus quintus. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter sister and (Presently after) master Courtwell.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I cannot forget my careless gentleman; his neglect and reproaches have wrought strangely upon me; he's here.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Is there not a weasel crept in to your chamber, lady.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: A weasel sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes, a monsieur Suck-egg.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Do you take my chamber for a hen's nest, sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: There's a thing that calls himself device, one that will break the heart of a post-horse to continue a hand gallop with him, your a la mode, your fighting fairy, feathered footed servant, when saw you him?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: My fighting servant, has he beaten you sir? perhaps he thought you were his rival: surely I saw him not since yesterday.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: By'r lady how many mile is it to the next cutler? the rogue has pawned or sold my sword.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Do you hear sir? I can tell you now what lady; it was you did abuse so

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I abuse a lady? Tell me the slave reported it; I hope it will prove this monsieur if ere we meet again; — who was it?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p:
Upon condition sir you will requite
me but with one gentle favour.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: You must sit down and hear me then, while at a distance, thus deliver.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: 'Tis more state.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I am most unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: For what dear damosel?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: And wronged by a gentleman I loved.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Can he be a gentleman that dares wrong so much love and beauty? what 's the offence?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: He will not love again.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: And you would have the stubborn man corrected?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I would be revenged, if I know how, and honour him, should do me justice.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Name the man: I'll do it.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: How.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Yet turn your face: alas! it is yourself: I have your word to punish him.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Sweet lady I am well acquainted with the worthy gentleman, but will not kill nor strike him: for I know he has just reason not to love you, you, of all your sex; he told me so.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: His reason?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
Was in these words, suppose you hear him speak it. Now do you sit; lady; when I consider you to a perfect form of what we can call handsome with all your attributes of soul and body where no addition or detraction can by Cupid's, nicer critics find a fault, or Mercury with your
eternal frame and then consider what a thing I am to this high character of you; so low so lost to noble merits, I despair to love a mistress cannot love again.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: This is as much dissembled modesty.

sp.speaker: Court.
