sp.p: No let it all alone, I have other reasons, lady, among my papers, to love, or to be in love is to be gulled, that's the plain English of Cupid's Latin besides, all reverence to the calling, I have vowed never to marry: and you know, love may bring a man to 't at last and therefore my fine gewgaw, do not abuse me.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: How can I when you will neither love me nor marry me?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I was not made for a husband.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: But I would make you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I know what you would make me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Monsieur device if you be alone would present his service to you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Is he come?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Do me but one favour, I'll recant my love, I will not have so much as one good thought of you, I will neglect you, sir, but for three minutes.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I'll have patience so long. He hides.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Admit him. I will be revenged on somebody? now sir:Enter device.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I've brought you a weapon lady.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Me, what to do sir.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: 'Tis justice I present it to your feet, whose love armed me to vindicate your honour.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: My honour?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: This is but the first of my valour in your cause; if you affect these monuments, I'll make you up an armoury: mean time receive my service with this sword; if he provoke me to fight with him again; I'll cut his hand off and bring it with me, to present the next.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Whose hand dear servant?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: He is not worth the naming, alas; this does not deserve your knowledge; only think what I dare do, when your bright name is questioned: and I in time may merit to be called the darling of your virgin thoughts.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Pray stay; my name traduced? who was so impudent? do me the grace to let me know on whom your valour has been exercised.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Why upon the formal thing, called Courtwell, I would call him gentleman, but that I have baffled him; you need no other witness then his sword:She shuts the door.with the fine holiday hilt.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Look you sir I have made fast the door because I mean before you go, to have a satisfaction for the base injury you have done me.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I done you injury?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p:
Not that I value Courtwell whom you would pretend has been too saucy with my honour, but cause I scorn to own a goodness should depend upon your sword or vindication: I'll fight with thee myself in this
small volume against your bulk in folio.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Excellent wench.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I was your champion, lady.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I had rather have no fame then have thee name it; thou fight for a lady's honour, and disarm a gentleman? thou fence before the pageants and make room for the porters, when like elephants they carry once a year the city castles: or go a feasting with the drum or school boys to the bank side and save the bears a whipping that day: come sir I mean to have about with you.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: At what weapon?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: This, and none other, sir.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I'll rather bleed to death then lift a sword in my defence ▪ whose inconsiderate brightness may fright the roses from your cheeks, and leave the lilies to lament the rude divorce: but were a man to dare me, and your enemy, my rage more nimble than the Median shaft should fly into his bosom, and your eye change anger into smiles, to see me fight and cut him into a ragged staff.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I cannot hold no longer; you have got a stomach sir with running, I'll try how you can eat a sword.

sp.speaker: Dev
sp.p: Have you an ambush lady; I'll cry out murder, 'tis two to one. Fair play!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Let me but cut one leg off to mar his running.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Hold: let me speak.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What canst thou say for thy baseness?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Some men love wit, and can without dishonour endure a jest; why? do you think I knew not you were here and but observed to see my humour? I came to wait upon you with your sword.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: How came you by it? Confess before this lady.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Dost think her wit's so limber to believe I could compel it from thee, 'twas a trick, a mere conceit of mirth, thou shalt have mine: dost think I stand upon a sword? I'll give thee a case of pistols, when we come to London; and shoot me when I love thee not: pox on it, thou apprehendest me well enough.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: But I am not satisfied, do you love this gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Hum;

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You will resolve sir.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: As may become a stranger; I will not lose thy friendship for all woman kind.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: He dares, not own you.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I easily forgive him: I should hate myself if I depended on his pity.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Thou art a noble wench: shall we leave of these jigs, and speak our minds in earnest by these twin lips, I love thee extremely.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Swear by your own.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: They shall be mine: monsieur, for your penance you shall a long and witness.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: What I pray.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: The priest shall tell you, come, we have both dissembled, we do love one another.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: 'Tis not possible.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Unless you will deny me in the church. I have vowed to lie with you this night: device, amble before, and find the parson out; we will be friends, and thou shalt be her father.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I must maintain my honour, or be beaten.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Come we'll have no more acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Very pretty! I may deceive you yet for all your confidence.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: If the sky fall, we'll have the darks to supper. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter lady sir Francis and Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: It was a strange neglect, sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I confess it, and not deserve to live for it, yet if you but knew my sufferings.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Let her be judge.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: By no means madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You may trust her knowledge.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: This is worse than a whipping now, these ladies have no mercy on a delinquent; I must stand to it; there is no tyrant to a chambermaid, made judge in such a case; I'll give a limb to be quit now; but if she choose, I am a cripple for this world.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Is it possible? A man and such a beast?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: So: I must to the shambles.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What punishment can be equal to the offence?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
He looks with some compunction for his fault, troth, madam, such another
night: and try whether he'll sleep again.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Merciful wench; if we piece again; it shall be a good turn in thy way.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: My husband is resolved this day for London. It is his humour, or else worse, suspicion: there's no pretence for him to stay behind.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You have made ill use of your time sir Francis; I know not how to help you; seven years hence you may have such another opportunity.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Watch if my husband come not this way, Dorothy, well sir, though your transgression deserve no pardon, yet I am charitable upon condition.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Any thing, madam: this shows excellent in you. No penance shall displease, so you absolve me. Bid me to climb some rock or pyramid, upon whose narrow spear you have advanced my peace, and I will reach it, or else fall lost to the world in my contempt.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You speak gloriously, the condition that assures your pardon, is only this, that you conclude, here, all your loose desires, with a resolve never to prosecute or hope to enjoy me:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Call you this charity, let me rather lose your pardon, than ever be thus divorced: bind me never to see you, (And yet that were cruelty) then, charm me to forget that I am man, or have a heart, and you a beauty which your absence can as well make nothing, as divide from my adoring
it is not cure but killing to prescribe I never must enjoy you, if you have resolved death upon me, let it be when we like lovers have embraced.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: It is not possible.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Nothing in love can be impossible to willing minds. I'll tell you, madam, sure the devil has forsworn the flesh, there may be a plot, I have it. An excellent rare device, if you but favour it: your husband is immediately for London I must in modesty ride with him; you are left behind.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: How can that profit you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What a deal of submission these foolish men trouble us women with, that are more forward to be friends again, than they?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I will counterfeit a fall.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: A fall?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ay, from my horse, observe me then.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My confederate I hope by this time is at the gate inquiring for sir Richard very formally from the old knight his master and good lady: the follow has wit to manage it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My footman shall pretend himself the surgeon to attend me; is't not rare? stand but to it fate in this and if I fail I will sit down a convert and renounce all wanton hope hereafter. Dearest madam if you did mean this honour to me before let not your loving thoughts freeze in a minute; my genius is a prophet.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir Richard, madam, is coming this way.

sp.speaker: Fran
sp.p: Shall I hope again

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I will not say you shall despair.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You bless me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My business is on foot, your jewel madam will credit much the cause.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: We will with draw; and let me know how you, have cast the plot. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter sir Richard (Opening a letter) and footman.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: From thy master? his name?

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: Sir William Litleland.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I do not know him.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: His name is well known in Lincolnshire near the fens; there were of his family ancient gentlemen before the conquest, some say, ever since the flood,

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Little land?

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: But he has now more land than 3. of the best of the sheer, thank the Dutch men that have drunk up all the water.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: They water — drinkers?

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: Why not, as well as eat dry land? they are lined with butter; sir; they fear no dropsies.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.

body.p:
She has been absent these two years, the occasion her dislike and disaffection to a gentleman whom I confess, I did severely urge her to marry, if she have lived with you, as my late intelligence informs me in the nature of a servant, which is beneath my wish and her condition, I hope upon this knowledge, you will with consider of her quality she being my
only child and heir to my fortunes, use her like a gentlewoman: and though my pears have made me unfit for travel I do intend upon the return of my daughter, whom I shall receive as a new blessing from you, to express myself for your favour

closer.signed: Your true friend and servant William Litteland.

sp.p: My maid Dorothy a knight's daughter and heir? do you know your young mistress?

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: I shall be happy to see her, with a letter and token from her lady mother.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I pray trust me to deliver it.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: Ay, with all my heart, sir; you may command.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Thomas, pray entertain this footman in the buttery: let him drink and refresh himself and set the cold chine of beef before him he has run hard.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: That will stay his stomach indeed; but claret is his only binder.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: Sack while you live after a heat, sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Pease you, I'll show you the way to be drunk. Exit with footman.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: To my loving daughter? may not this be a trick? Enter Underwit.
By your favour madam; captain, gather you the sense of that letter, while I peruse this, you know mistress Dorothy?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p:
I have had a great desire to know her,
I confess, but she is still like the bottom of the map, terra incognita, I have been a long time hovering about the Magellan straits but have made no new discoveries.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Ha! this is no counterfeit; I dare trust my own judgement; 'tis a very rich one I am confirmed, and I will seal them up again. My lady's woman sir William Littleland's daughter and heir? what say you now of mistress Dorothy?

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: A great deal better than I did, and yet I have loud her this half year in a kind of way, of my conscience, why may not I marry her?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: This jewel was sent by her mother to her.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Dear uncle conceal it till I have talk with her, o for some witchcraft to make all sure.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I like this well: she's here.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: I vow, mistress Dorothy; if I were immodest, it was the mere impudence of my sack, and not my own disposition but if you please to accept my love now by the way of marriage I'll make you satisfaction, like a gentleman in the point of honour.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Your birth and estate is too high and unequal for me, sir.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: What care I for portion or a face, she that has good eyes, has good — give me virtue.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You are pleased to make your mirth of me.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: By this ruby nay; you shall wear it in the broad eye of the world; dost think I jest?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir Richard: —

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: If he were ten sir Richard's, I am out of my wardship

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How he flutters in the limebush: it takes rarely. Aside.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: What a necessary thing were a household chaplain? Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: So; so; the wench inclines, I will hasten my journey that I may appear with more excuse, when they are married in my absence. Exit.

div.stage: Enter master Courtwell, sister and device.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Come we are fast enough, and now I have thee, I'll tell the all the fault I find, thou hast a little two much wit, to be a wife: it could not be too nimble for a mistress. There is a part of your penance still behind device; you would pretend to be a poet, I'll not disgrace the name to call thee one, but let me have times against we go to bed, two anagrams that weigh an ounce with comment, and after that, in verse your affidavit that you do wish us joy, and I'll discharge you.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: 'Tis time I were at study then.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
About them, your double congee, and depart with silence: now prithee tell me who reported I had wronged a lady? Was it
not thy revenge to make me angry?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: It was indeed now tell me; why at the first approach seemed you so modest? you have confidence to spare, now.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Troth I came not with any wooing purpose: only to please my uncle, and try thy wit and that converted me. Enter Tho.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Did you see my master captain Underwit?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes he's talking with a priest and mistress Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Her father's footman is here, she is a knight's daughter and heir, but she doth not know it.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I think so?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Where's my uncle?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A mile on his way to London, by this time with sir Richard, I long to see my master. Exit.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: We shall want company to dance.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: My sister.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: If you please madam, you may call me, brother, we have been at, I John take thee Elisabeth, a posset and four naked thighs in a bed tonight , we'll bid fair earnest for a boy too.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: 'Tis even so madam; the priest has done it

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Nay then all joys attend you; if this had been known, it might have, stayed sir Richard, and your uncle one day more.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Room for another couple.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: In hell, my master is married.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: My husband left some letters, and a token was sent you mistress Dorothy, you did ill to obscure yourself so much, you shall not want hereafter all respects that may become you.

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.p: Madam I know not what you mean.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: She will not take it upon her, yet.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: There is the sportEnter device.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: O madam, news; ill news; an accident which will blast all your mirth, sir Francis; —

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What of him.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Has broke; —

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: His neck?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: You guess very near it, 'tis but, his shoulder has saved that joint; a fall from his horse they say hath much endangered him.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: My uncle hurt? Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: He has kept his word; now if he counterfeit handsomely.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Monsieur device, I must entreat a courtesy: you have wit and I will have a masque to entertain my new father in law sir William Littleland; mistress Dorothy now my wife is his only daughter and heir

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.p: Who has gulled you thus? I am no knights daughter.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Give you joy captain

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: She is still loath to confess it.

div.stage: Enter sir Francis; master Courtwell, lady, sister, Sackbury.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: If you love charity; a bone setter.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: He counterfeits rarely, where is sir Richard.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He rid before, but I sent my footman, to tell him my misfortune; o; madam.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: This is better than the tooth ache; he carries it excellently.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ask me no torturing questions, I desire madame a little conference with you, I'll thank the rest if they will with draw.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Let's leave him.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: We'll to my chamber, captain.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: You have a mind to examine the business privately.

sp.speaker: Und
sp.p: No, good captain you may be present, come; Thomas, thou shalt be witness too. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: They are gone, you feign most artificially, let me embrace you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O take heed.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What's the matter.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Tis no dissembling, madam; I have had a fall indeed: a dreadful fall, I feel it, I think my horse saw the devil in some hedge, ere I had rid three furlongs: gave a start, pitched me off his back like a bar and broke a flint with my shoulder, I think; which struck fire too there was something like it in my eyes; I am punished.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: But is this serious, are you hurt indeed?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Hurt? I have broke my shoulder, feelingly, and I am of opinion when I do enjoy you, madam, I shall break my neck: that will be the next; I'll take this for a
warning and will leave of in time.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: It makes me tremble.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I will be honest now, and so forgive me, is not the surgeon come yet?

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Heaven hath cured us both.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I am not cured yet, o for the bone setter, if ever I counterfeit again.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: There is a blessing fallen upon my blood: your only thoughts charm had power to make my thoughts wicked, and your conversion disenchants me: may both our lives be such as heaven may not grieve, to have showed this bounty.

div.stage: Enter Courtwell and the rest with sir Richard.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Sir Richard; madame:

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You may enter now, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I do not like this stratagem, sir Francis must not here practise his court tricks, I will not trust my wife's surgery:
He's come;Sir Francis is led out.
How is it noble sir Francis; best with draw, I'll see him dressed myself.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Madam and gentleman; mistress Dorothy will not acknowledge she is a knight's daughter she swears she knows no Littleland.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Till it appear to whom, this gem was meant, deaf madam, be you treasurer, I confess I have wealth enough in such a noble husband.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: It shall belong to thee; be honest Dorothy, and use him well.

sp.speaker: D●r..
sp.p: With my best study, madam;

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Where is this footman you talk of?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: He pretended letters to carry two miles off to a kinsman's of his masters and return presently: he drunk 3. or 4. beer glasses of sack and he run away so lightly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: His reward shall overtake him.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Will you have her; she'll do you service, captain at a low country leager or thou Thomas I le give thee a copyhold.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: You have one life to come in that lease yet, I thank you I am free, and that is inheritance. For ought I know she may serve us both.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Come you may persuade her to take it upon her for your credit, the gullery is yet with in these walls let your shames go no further, the wench may prove right; she may.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What news from sir Francis.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Wife I heartily ask thy forgiveness: I had jealous thoughts, but all is right again.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: I will deserve your confidence.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: No great danger, his blade bone dislocated: the man has put every thing in his right place

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Do you hear sir Richard, we are married.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis well done 'tis to my mind, send you joy;

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: Come hither Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My mother died, I have it by tradition, so, as soon as I was born my father but no knight, is now in the Indies a poor merchant that broke for 20000.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: The ships may come home, ha;

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You had best use me well now we are married, I will be sworn you forced me to the church and thrice compelled me there to said, I Dorothy — the parson's oath and mine, for ought I know may make it half a rape.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: There is no remedy we can prove no conspiracy; and because I have been gulled myself, get her with child; my doe is barren, at birth of her first baby I'll give thee a hundred pieces.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: That's somewhat yet: when charge coms on, thy hand, a wife can be but a wife: it shall cost me 500. but I'll make thee a lady in earnest.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: How is it sir Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My surgeon says no danger: when you please I may venture sir to London.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: No hast now.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Not tonight , sir, we must have revels, and you salute my bride.

sp.speaker: Und.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A knight's daughter and heir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
May all joys thrive upon your Jove's; than you are cozened of your mistress monsieur, but your nephew knows
I have met with my match if not put to the worst.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Come we lose time.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Preserve your marriage faith: a full increase of what you wish confirm your happiness.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
